history.content:
I did this combo right after finishing 70 (with a safe A, for you to gauge, but of course there is a lot of bias here). I have to admit this combo is a little bit overwhelming even only taking these two tech courses, but not impossible to handle if you are comfortable with long math problem sets.

Homework set: Both have long and hard homework sets. Both of them took way more time to finish than my math 110's homework set. Going to OH's extremely helpful for both courses. 

Labs: Only 126 has labs. 8 or 9 labs. Not bad in general. Some will take longer to finish since the concepts are hard to digest.

Midterm: Both have 2 midterms. Both hard. PLAN EARLY. In my semester, 170 and 126's 1 and 2 midterms are in separate weeks which made things a little bit better. 

Project: Both have a final team project. Will eat up several weeks after Thanksgiving. I'm very lucky to have some great teammates so it's not bad. But my friends aren't so lucky and complained a lot about the team dynamic. 

126's very important if you want to do 189 in the future. Also, this was two years ago, course content might change; things might be different due to the online format. 

Overall, It's definitely a very fulfilling semester and I learned a lot! But looking back, I kind of hope that I could separate these two courses, especially because both courses cover tricky and important concepts that need time to digest if it's one's first time seeing them(DM, reductions in 170; HMC, MLE/MAP, kalman filter in 126). I remembered clearly that I found some topics extremely intriguing but had to strategically NOT diving too deep into it so that I could have even time for reviewing the final for both courses.

Just my two cents. Hope it helps!

children.subject: 61C was really time consuming for me (perhaps more so than 126) because the projects are pretty tedious, and I spent a ton of time fixing bugs. I think either way the combo of 61C + 126 or 170 + 126 is doable, but I found it easier to kind of skim past hard parts of 170 and come back to them when I had time, whereas for 61C, I think it's hard to skip past things and review them when you have time because of the nature of the class and project deadlines and such

I agree that 61C's more time consuming than 170 or 126--it has hard concepts, runs fast, and those 4 projects are all time-consuming. I think 61C + 170 is a pretty common combo among my friends, which is somewhat doable as this too courses complement each other in terms of the content and also open a lot of future courses both in EE and CS for you to study.

170 + 61c has been done by a lot of people I know. It depends on how good you are with probability. If you're pretty decent and found the end of 70 fairly easy, maybe 170 and 126 will be easier. 61c, regardless of your prior knowledge, will probably be time consuming anyway because the projects are pretty time consuming.

I agree with Wesley. It's going to be overwhelming. I did that last Fall and that remains one of my biggest regret at Berkeley. You could make less overwhelming by studying for one of them during the summer.
Did you have any extra background for 170? Like USACO (I don't)

Nope, and to be honest there are sections in 170 I still don't fully get, but I think a lot of it (DP, runtime) was pretty intuitive for me. And I ended up PNPing the course anyway last semester (though I ended up with an A- I think)

I also did this combo. It is definitely doable. For me, I did okay in 70 but didn't fully understand the probability section, so 126 is where I spent a ton of my time. Both classes are homework heavy, but I wouldn't say that it was necessarily too much.

history.content: I'm a sophomore. I got a low A in CS70, although the better midterm for me was the probability one. A's in 61a/b, and I took 16a and Math 110 DPNP (around B+'s). I plan on taking a breadth as well. What would this workload look like weekly, and could I understand the material for these two classes very well at the same time? My thoughts were to grind out these two classes this sem, and then cruise with 1 (maybe 2) upper div a semester while exploring other classes or double major, knowing that I have much of the major done. The alternative would be to spread it out even more.
history.subject: 170+126 workload
